reporting-org.narrative: Ethiopian Women with Disabilities national Association

title.narrative: AWESOME(Advancing Women's Engagement Strengthening opportunities to mobilize for Equality

description.narrative: A 5 year advocacy programme to support women’s movements in Ethiopia, Kenya and Uganda to be strengthened, less fragmented and more representative of diverse groups of women, including women with disabilities. These stronger women’s movements will contribute to strong women leaders at all levels, and the prevention and elimination of sexual and gender based violence (SGBV) against women and girls.

participating-org.narrative: Ethiopian Women with Disabilities national Association
Ethiopian Women with Disabilities national Association

title.narrative: An increase in community members (including leaders) demonstrating support for gender equality and the rights of women with disabilities
Number of community members showing support for women's rights in SGBV

description.narrative: Society 2.4: Number of community members (including leaders) who demonstrate support for gender equality and rights of WwDs (50% in SGBV, and 50% in participation and leadership)

comment.narrative: Awareness raising programs are recommended to increase the participation level of all stakeholders, including communityleaders. Currently attitude is that WWD are not deliberately excluded. However there are no provisions made for WWD. Disability is considered an individual problem. Lack of participation is blamed on WWD, there is positive marginalisation of WWD and GWD and they are general asked to stay home and so doing limiting participation of women and girls with disabilites in community life.

CBO leaders in our context are: Local leaders (Idir leaders) and religious leaders. In this case the majority 70% are Idir leader who have a day to day contact with the community. The remaining 30% of the target groups are faith based organization leaders
In Ethiopian community, it is males who will be leader of a community based organizations and in terms of age usually those above the age of 65+ who have retired from formal employment are highly preferred, as they are believed to be matured in one hand and have time to manage community issues accompanied by the respect they will get from the society to be heard increases as age increases.
Attitidues that will change in 5 years end all discrimination by family members and the community in general, and for community leaders to recognise unconcious bias towards to WWDs and recognise the independence of WWD and their ability to be active participants in their own lives and in society

title.narrative: Number of community members showing support for women's rights in leadership and participation

description.narrative: Society 2.4: Number of community members (including leaders) who demonstrate support for gender equality and rights of WwDs (50% in SGBV, and 50% in participation and leadership)

comment.narrative: Awareness raising programs are recommended to increase the participation level of all stakeholders, including communityleaders. Currently attitude is that WWD are not deliberately excluded. However there are no provisions made for WWD. Disability is considered an individual problem. Lack of participation is blamed on WWD, there is positive marginalisation of WWD and GWD and they are general asked to stay home and so doing limiting participation of women and girls with disabilites in community life.

CBO leaders in our context are: Local leaders (Idir leaders) and religious leaders. In this case the majority 70% are Idir leader who have a day to day contact with the community. The remaining 30% of the target groups are faith based organization leaders

title.narrative: Women's rights organisation (WRO) partners in the AWESOME Alliance with strengthened capacities
Number of women's rights organisation (WRO) partners in the AWESOME Alliance with strengthened capacities

comment.narrative:
AWESOME recognises that strengthening women’s organisations is crucial in maintaining and widening the space for voice, visibility, advocacy and evidence about violations of women’s rights in their regions. We also acknowledge that “L&A capacities” is a very subjective statement in terms of both the nature and the magnitude of change. AWESOME is committed to supporting partner organisations (and our own organisation) to build their sustainability, resilience and capabilities, through feminist organisational development and exchange, and connection to a wider network of similar organisations. Because partner organisations are very different in terms of capacity, staff size, budgets and so on, we’ve worked with partners during the inception period to understand the individual support needs from each organisation, ensuring a tailored and comprehensive approach to capacity strengthening.
By increased capacities we mean all types of capacity building and support offered through AWESOME (such as the FOCS funding, safeguarding training, MEL training, Disability and Inclusion training etc).
EWDNA is a member based organization who needs to do diverse interventions to make sure that our organizational goal is achieved and to ensure that the rights of WWDs are well recognized in Ethiopia. But its capacity to deliver in terms of finance, human resource and networking is limited. Using the organizational capacity building support in AWESOME (using FOCS resources), EWDNA would like to see:
• Its visibility and networking improved/increased
• Increase its organizational capacity to deliver through increased finance and human resource base
• Would like to have a digital data management system(this is already in progress with FOCS support)
• Organizational level M and E system in place(already in progress)
• Increase participation of our members in planning, implementation and monitoring and Evaluation cycles
Qualitative description of annual progress will be reported, towards the overall target.
Qualitative description of annual progress will be reported, towards the overall target.
Qualitative description of annual progress will be reported, towards the overall target.
Qualitative description of annual progress will be reported, towards the overall target.

By the end of AWESOME, using the organizational capacity building support in AWESOME (using FOCS resources), EWDNA would like to see: • Its visibility and networking improved/increased • Increase its organizational capacity to deliver through increased finance and human resource base • Would like to have a digital data management system(this is already in progress with FOCS support) • Organizational level M and E system in place(already in progress) • Increase participation of our members in planning, implementation and monitoring and Evaluation cycles

title.narrative: An increase in gender sensitive and disability inclusive coverage and reporting in the media
Number of media spots that promote women’s (including WwDs) rights related to SGBV

description.narrative: Society 2.5: Number of radio shows played (140 focused on disability inclusion in women's participation and leadership on 8 March International Women's Day; and 140 shows will be SGBV focused and played during 16 Days of Activism).

comment.narrative: Although media is a powerful tool to bring behavioral change, and media can strengthen the voices of diverse women to champion a new narrative around gender equality, 41% of baseline respondents believe that their issue is not addressed by the media. Baseline value is 0 because no AWESOME media has been created yet.

Our target is for the voices of WWds to be included in media programmes. This will be 7 radio programs, played twice a year (on disability and women's international days), across 4 regions. One message that is translated into local languages, and shares the voices of diverse women. The longer-term change we are seeking is that WDROs no longer have to pay for inclusion in media programming voices of WWDs included in media programmes.

title.narrative: Number of media spots that promote women’s (including WwDs) rights related to participation and leadership

description.narrative: Society 2.5: Number of radio shows played (140 focused on disability inclusion in women's participation and leadership on 8 March International Women's Day; and 140 shows will be SGBV focused and played during 16 Days of Activism).

comment.narrative: Although media is a powerful tool to bring behavioral change, and media can strengthen the voices of diverse women to champion a new narrative around gender equality, 41% of baseline respondents believe that their issue is not addressed by the media. Baseline value is 0 because no AWESOME media has been created yet.

Our target is for the voices of WWds to be included in media programmes. This will be 7 radio programs, played twice a year (on disability and women's international days), across 4 regions. One message that is translated into local languages, and shares the voices of diverse women. The longer-term change we are seeking is that WDROs no longer have to pay for inclusion in media programming voices of WWDs included in media programmes.

title.narrative: Increased collective advocacy efforts by women's rights organisation (WRO) actors for policy change and legal reform, national and regional level
Number of influencing spaces attended or facilitated related to SGBV and participation

description.narrative: Formal institutions 3.5: Number of public events and national events held

comment.narrative: EWDNA has been hosting multiple regional events for the past 20 years, but with AWESOME we will focus more on these events at national level meaning participation from different regions of the country, which we see as important to have representation and to make the implementation uniform.
Of the 9 public events, only 2 are at national level ( 1 in year 4 and 1 in year 5), other are all regional (e.g. one region of Amhara, or SNNPR within Ethiopia) and local level events.

title.narrative: Number of influencing spaces attended or facilitated related to SGBV and participation

description.narrative: Formal institutions 3.5: Number of public events and national events held

comment.narrative: EWDNA has been hosting multiple regional events for the past 20 years, but with AWESOME we will focus more on these events at national level meaning participation from different regions of the country, which we see as important to have representation and to make the implementation uniform.

title.narrative: Evidence of policy and legal reform related to sexual and gender based violence (SGBV), women’s rights and participation, and specifically the rights of women with disabilities.
Number of policies and laws on sexual and gender based violence (SGBV) and women’s participation are strengthened in their frameworks, ratification and/or implementation.

description.narrative: Formal Institutions, Outcome 3.1: Acceptance of the gaps in Penal Code of Ethiopia

comment.narrative: EWDNA in collaboration with like-minded organizations such EWLA and should lobby for the revision of Penal Code. The current penal code does not make provisions for WWDs and EWDNA will be working to get the penal code improved by ensuring it is inclusive of WWD. [EWDNA's year 2 target is to identify the legal gaps, which will help EWDNA to expand on this baseline in terms of the current status of the Penal Code]

EWDNA's target is to evidence increased acceptance of the stakeholders on the legal gaps in Penal Code of Ethiopia. The current penal code does not make provisions for WWDs and EWDNA will be working to get the penal code improved by ensuring it is inclusive of WWD. This will begin with identification of legal gaps in Year 2. In Year 3, EWDNA will raise stakeholders' awarenes on the lgeal gaps. In Year 4, we hope to see willingness of concerned government officials to make revisions.
Penal Code: a code of laws concerning crimes and offenses and their punishment.
Acceptance of gaps means (or would look like)… commitment of the national government, inclusion of gaps in their next annual plan is the ultimate aim, taking EWDNA's inputs as valuable will be considered as a success (if they accept Penal Code has a gap will be a milestone achivement, may not be written, might be about them giving a welcoming environment and oral discussions).
[EWDNA's work in year 2 will identify the legal gaps in the Penal Code,

title.narrative: An increase in the number and diversity of women supported with training, awareness raising, and networking
Number of women supported with training, awareness raising, and networking.

description.narrative: Self 1.2: Number of women (yellow movement member university students, WWDs, women participating in the women’s movement) who report feeling their issues and needs have been recognized by the wider group.

comment.narrative:
WWDs stated that their issues are not well addressed by the movements. Only 15% of WWDs knew the existence of any active movements for WWDs, gender equality, disability, and SGBV.
This indicator is targeting: WROs, Yellow Movement leaders and WWDs through trainings and events.
Here youth movement participants are mainly targeted (75%) while WRO leaders (25%) are expected to be welcoming and give recognition to those gender movements in University.

Actively participating: WWDs attending 5 coffee sessions; elected leaders joining joint meetings and give speach about the issue; Yellow movement and WROs attending at least two EWDNA events per year.

Actively participating: WWDs attending 5 coffee sessions; elected leaders joining joint meetings and give speach about the issue; Yellow movement and WROs attending at least two EWDNA events per year.

Actively participating: WWDs attending 5 coffee sessions; elected leaders joining joint meetings and give speach about the issue; Yellow movement and WROs attending at least two EWDNA events per year.

Actively participating: WWDs attending 5 coffee sessions; elected leaders joining joint meetings and give speach about the issue; Yellow movement and WROs attending at least two EWDNA events per year.

500 women will actively participate in the women's movement. Womens movement becomes disability sensitive and WwDs are active participants in the womens movement.
Actively participating: WWDs attending 5 coffee sessions; elected leaders joining joint meetings and give speach about the issue; Yellow movement and WROs attending at least two EWDNA events per year.
